questiontext.text:
We define the relation, \(f\), to be the subset of \( \mathbb{Z} \times \mathbb{Z} \) such that

\( f=\{ ({@aa*m*n@}, {@bb*m+cc*n@}) : m,n \in \mathbb{Z} \} \)


Find two pairs of integers \((m_1, n_1)\) and \((m_2, n_2)\) that take the same value in the domain of the relation, but different values in the range.
This then shows that \(f\) is not a function.

\( m_{1} = \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] and \( n_{1} = \) [[input:ans1s]] [[validation:ans1s]]

\( m_{2} = \) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] and \( n_{2} = \) [[input:ans2s]] [[validation:ans2s]]

[[feedback:prt1]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked solution

We have the relation,

\( f=\{ ({@aa*m*n@}, {@bb*m+cc*n@}) : m,n \in \mathbb{Z} \} \)

We require two pairs of integer coordinates \((m,n)\) where the values in the domain of the relation, \({@aa*m*n@}\), are the same.
For this we can choose any number with a non-unique factorization, so any non-prime integer, then take \(m\) and \(n\) to be the different pairs of factors.
For example, choosing {@t_ans1*t_ans1s@} we have distinct factorizations,

\({@t_ans1*t_ans1s@} = {@t_ans1@} \times {@t_ans1s@}\)
\({@t_ans1*t_ans1s@} = {@t_ans2@} \times {@t_ans2s@}\)


We also require that the value of the pairs of integers are different in the range of the relation, \({@bb*m + cc*n@}\),
We can verify that this is the case in the above example.

For \((m,n) = ({@t_ans1@}, {@t_ans1s@})\), we have \({@bb*m+cc*n = bb*t_ans1+cc*t_ans1s@}\)

For \((m,n) = ({@t_ans2@}, {@t_ans2s@})\), we have \({@bb*m+cc*n = bb*t_ans2+cc*t_ans2s@}\)

Therefore we may take

\((m_1,n_1) = ({@t_ans1@}, {@t_ans1s@})\)

\((m_2,n_2) = ({@t_ans2@}, {@t_ans2s@})\)


In particular, \(f\) cannot be a function since,

\(f({@aa*t_ans1*t_ans1s@}) = f({@aa@} \cdot {@t_ans1@} \cdot {@t_ans1s@}) = {@bb@} \cdot {@t_ans1@} + {@cc@} \cdot {@t_ans1s@} = {@bb*t_ans1 + cc*t_ans1s@}\)
\(f({@aa*t_ans2*t_ans2s@}) = f({@aa@} \cdot {@t_ans2@} \cdot {@t_ans2s@}) = {@bb@} \cdot {@t_ans2@} + {@cc@} \cdot {@t_ans2s@} = {@bb*t_ans2 + cc*t_ans2s@}\)

So, since \({@bb*t_ans1 + cc*t_ans1s@} \neq {@bb*t_ans2 + cc*t_ans2s@}\), \(f\) is not a well-defined function.

falsefeedback.text:
For the pairs of integers which you have given, the values in the range of the relation are not the same and nor are the values in the domain different.

Remember that a relation. \(R\), from \(A\) to \(B\) is a subset of the Cartesian product \(A \times B\).

Then the domain of the relation is the set of first coordinates of the elements of \(R\), so,

\(\text{Dom}(R) = \{a \in A : (a,b) \in R\} \)

Similarly, the range of the relation is the set of second coordinates of the elements of \(R\), so,

\(\text{Range}(R) = \{b \in B : (a,b) \in R\)
